Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Oxide Scale Development in Coated High-Temperature Alloys for Solid-Oxide Fuel Cell Interconnects

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) project is to elucidate the mechanisms that are responsible for structural evolution in conductive oxide coatings on high-temperature alloy interconnects for solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs). The research will result in a more fundamental understanding of the roles of interdiffusion, reaction layer formation and applied electric field on the structural and electrical characteristics of oxide coatings. The research approach utilizes pulsed laser deposition to produce model coatings with the chemistries of current generation SOFC coatings and interlayers but with morphologies that are better suited to well-controlled mechanistic studies. Post-deposition structural development in model coatings and interlayers will be characterized as a function of exposure conditions using advanced ion- and electron-beam analysis techniques. The data obtained from the model coatings/interlayers will be used as critical inputs to multi-layer models of oxide scale development and properties. The successful completion of this project will provide the basis for better predictive modeling of lifetimes for existing coated alloy SOFC interconnects and of the properties for new coatings with superior properties.

This GOALI project is a collaboration between the University of Connecticut (UConn) and United Technologies Research Center (UTRC) and will involve both full-time UConn graduate students and UTRC employees pursuing UConn graduate degrees on a part-time basis. These students will benefit both from formal graduate education and from hands-on training through involvement in the research at both sites. The students will also be involved in the broader educational outreach activities of the group aimed at bringing an appreciation of MSE to local K-12 students. Key results from the research will be disseminated through: publication in the open literature, presentation at conferences, workshops held at UTRC, and integration of examples into outreach materials.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Intermediate temperature solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) will play an important role in the development of a sustainable energy infrastructure, because they are more efficient and fuel-flexible than other fuel cells, but they are cheaper and more durable than high-temperature SOFCs. One of the main advantages of intermediate temperature SOFCs is that the interconnects between the cells can be made of metallic alloys such as stainless steels, rather than from conducting ceramics.  These alloys are cheaper, more conductive, more formable, and more durable than ceramics, but they still require coatings to prevent them from oxidizing too quickly during SOFC operation. The aim of this program was to develop an understanding of: the way that current generation coatings made of manganese cobaltite interact with the alloy substrate, how they inhibit alloy oxidation, and thus how better coating chemistries could be developed. This was accomplished by using advanced X-ray, electron and ion beam techniques to evaluate the oxidation behavior of the interconnect alloy Crofer 22APU in the uncoated condition and after coating with manganese cobaltite. The coatings were applied using industry standard reactive consolidation of powder slurries, and by pulsed laser deposition to give dense model coatings. The main outcomes of these studies are as follows:

The oxidation behavior of the bare alloy depends critically on the alloy structure. Alloys in commercial strip form exhibit much higher oxidation rates and more chromium-rich scales than alloys heat-treated to give coarse grain structures. This demonstrates that microstructure control has a key role to play in inhibiting oxidation for such alloys.

The oxidation of the slurry-coated alloy is much more limited than that of the corresponding bare alloy. This is accompanied by the formation of a complex reaction layer at the alloy-coating interface. The chemistry of the reaction layer develops with exposure time and reaches steady state after around 1000 hours of exposure. Since the electrical properties of the reaction layer will depend on the chemical composition, this layer could have a profound effect upon the behavior of the coated alloy.

Studies on the reactive consolidation process revealed that many of the characteristics of the reaction layer are established at the very earliest stages of reactive consolidation. Thus, even during the initial reduction step, there is oxidation occurring at the interface leading to a complex mixture of oxide phases and morphologies.

Model ceramic manganese cobaltites were produced with different levels of chromium, iron and nickel additions. These were investigated using X-ray spectrometry channeling experiments to reveal the role that each of these ions might play in the development of reaction layers for coated alloys. It was found that there are strong site occupancy preferences for each of these ions, and these preferences could have a dramatic influence on the reactions occurring.

Model manganese cobaltite coatings deposited using pulsed laser deposition had rather more simple structures. The as-deposited coatings contained reduced phases that re-oxidized to manganese cobaltite upon ex-situ heat treatment. The structures observed in these coatings indicate that the orientation of the alloy substrate grains could play an important role in both the rate and mechanism of oxidation.

 

Broader Impacts: The more widespread adoption of SOFCs could have a dramatic impact upon the way in which energy is generated and distributed in the USA. Because SOFCs are much more fuel-flexible than other types of fuel cell, they can be implemented in locations where pure single-stream fuels such as hydrogen or methanol are not readily available. This would have a particularly profound impact in remote locations where the costs of ener...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Intellectual Merit: Intermediate temperature solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) will play an important role in the development of a sustainable energy infrastructure, because they are more efficient and fuel-flexible than other fuel cells, but they are cheaper and more durable than high-temperature SOFCs. One of the main advantages of intermediate temperature SOFCs is that the interconnects between the cells can be made of metallic alloys such as stainless steels, rather than from conducting ceramics. These alloys are cheaper, more conductive, more formable, and more durable than ceramics, but they still require coatings to prevent them from oxidizing too quickly during SOFC operation. The aim of this program was to develop an understanding of: the way that current generation coatings made of manganese cobaltite interact with the alloy substrate, how they inhibit alloy oxidation, and thus how better coating chemistries could be developed. This was accomplished by using advanced X-ray, electron and ion beam techniques to evaluate the oxidation behavior of the interconnect alloy Crofer 22APU in the uncoated condition and after coating with manganese cobaltite. The coatings were applied using industry standard reactive consolidation of powder slurries, and by pulsed laser deposition to give dense model coatings. The main outcomes of these studies are as follows: The oxidation behavior of the bare alloy depends critically on the alloy structure. Alloys in commercial strip form exhibit much higher oxidation rates and more chromium-rich scales than alloys heat-treated to give coarse grain structures. This demonstrates that microstructure control has a key role to play in inhibiting oxidation for such alloys. The oxidation of the slurry-coated alloy is much more limited than that of the corresponding bare alloy. This is accompanied by the formation of a complex reaction layer at the alloy-coating interface. The chemistry of the reaction layer develops with exposure time and reaches steady state after around 1000 hours of exposure. Since the electrical properties of the reaction layer will depend on the chemical composition, this layer could have a profound effect upon the behavior of the coated alloy. Studies on the reactive consolidation process revealed that many of the characteristics of the reaction layer are established at the very earliest stages of reactive consolidation. Thus, even during the initial reduction step, there is oxidation occurring at the interface leading to a complex mixture of oxide phases and morphologies. Model ceramic manganese cobaltites were produced with different levels of chromium, iron and nickel additions. These were investigated using X-ray spectrometry channeling experiments to reveal the role that each of these ions might play in the development of reaction layers for coated alloys. It was found that there are strong site occupancy preferences for each of these ions, and these preferences could have a dramatic influence on the reactions occurring. Model manganese cobaltite coatings deposited using pulsed laser deposition had rather more simple structures. The as-deposited coatings contained reduced phases that re-oxidized to manganese cobaltite upon ex-situ heat treatment. The structures observed in these coatings indicate that the orientation of the alloy substrate grains could play an important role in both the rate and mechanism of oxidation. Broader Impacts: The more widespread adoption of SOFCs could have a dramatic impact upon the way in which energy is generated and distributed in the USA. Because SOFCs are much more fuel-flexible than other types of fuel cell, they can be implemented in locations where pure single-stream fuels such as hydrogen or methanol are not readily available. This would have a particularly profound impact in remote locations where the costs of energy distribution are prohibitive and conventional local generation methods create too large of a carbon footprint. ...
